description: Neuroethology is the study of how nervous systems generate natural behaviors in animals.  The
nervous system connects an animal with its environment, determining how an animal perceives,
learns, and reacts to stimuli.  This course explores the neural mechanisms underlying diverse
behaviors - such as escape reflexes, locomotion, and communication - in a wide range of
invertebrate and vertebrate species and based on an evolutionary framework.  Lecture concepts are
explored through laboratory experimentation and different forms of scientific communication.
Students attend lectures plus one three-hour laboratory per week.  Offered in alternate years with
